newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electric futures fall amid ample hydropower.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electric futures fall amid ample hydropower.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures fell midday Wednesday amid a surplus of hydroelectricity being marketed in the western U.S., brokers and traders said.
Bonneville Power Adminstration (BPA) continued to offer daily power at competitive prices despite flagging regional power demand due to cooler weather.
BPA today expanded to sell non-firm, off-peak power for Thursday to the Southwest at $9.00 a megawatt hour (MWh).
The pace of trading was lackluster because of an industry function in Houston and more focus paid by energy participants to the oil complex amid escalating U.S.-Iraq tension.
October California-Oregon Border (COB) futures were down 11 cents at $16.05 per MWh.
November COB was at $16.45, erasing a 15 cent loss. Other active COB months were nine to 15 cents lower.
October Palo Verde (PV) futures, the only active contract in that half of the complex, were down 25 cents at $16.40.
In the physical market, October COB was last quoted at $15.90-$16.35, and October PV $16.25-$17.00.
At 1210 EDT, NYMEX said 69 COB and five PV were sold.
On Tuesday's close, COB open interest stood at 3,247 contracts, up 17, and PV OI ended at 936, up eight.
